Alissa Hirsh
Feb 10

Leaving Organized Sports Behind Hurts

Editor’s Note: Below is the introduction to a larger project which explores the strange period of time immediately following the end of a college athletics career. Its goals include 1) to pin-down exactly what makes an athlete’s connection to the game so strong and 2) to describe what becomes of this relationship when organized, competitive play ends.

The final game: an identity in question

There’s 1:44 left on the clock. We’re in a timeout down by twenty-seven and “Mony Mony” plays over the loudspeaker.

Under normal circumstances I dance along to time-out bangers, but right now I’m stunned into paralysis. As I walk back onto the court, I keep my eyes fixed on my feet. After a moment I look up and all of my teammates are crying.

What an odd way for this to end, I think.

Our opponents thrashed us from the tip, draining threes and defending smartly, so we never really got our feet off the ground. It’s a strange phenomenon of organized basketball — having to toss aside an entire week’s worth of strategizing in the game’s opening acts. Digging yourself out of a massive hole is never what you prepared for.

And then the whistle blows and we’re going as hard as we’ve ever gone and the bench is on their feet when we force turnovers and I’m living out every possession as if it’s a miniature version of my entire career. All that remains is a handful of opportunities to do what I love.

Accelerate, full-speed, veer, hard cross, hesitate — read — hesitate; duck and lean, lay it in. Wow. That was my move. Will I still be me without it?

A few days after the playoff loss that ended our college basketball careers, my teammate Anne and I found ourselves back in the gym. We spent an hour running shooting drills at the same frantic speed that we’d become accustomed to over the course of the season; we used the same critical lens to evaluate our progress.

“Dude, we probably look insane to anyone walking by,” I said as Anne lined up to take a free throw. “We’re literally not on the team anymore.”

Our eyes locked in recognition of the absurdity.

“The thing is, we’re still trying so hard,” she said.

Competition without the cutthroat approach

The way a college basketball player approaches the game is shaped by several core principles of competitive sports: 1) the stakes are high, 2) the outcome matters, and 3) every contest is to be treated as if it were a “life or death” battle. When players honor this unspoken agreement in concert, only then does the game reveal its purest form. That’s why I’m uneasy about what playing basketball will feel like when the stakes are removed and the treaty is broken. A world where it’s no big deal to not get back on defense, or miss a box-out, or toss a risky pass is one I can’t even imagine. It will be like looking at basketball through a funhouse mirror.

I wish I had known the stakes were a privilege. And I’m worried they’ve become so central to how I experience competition that I won’t be able to enjoy the game without them.

Luckily, there’s some evidence suggesting otherwise. My friend and fellow college athlete Dana Sherry once pointed out that whenever I’m struggling to turn my thoughts into words, all she has to do is suggest going for a walk. Dana’s right: I think more effectively when I’m moving, and a basketball game is the most obvious example. When players are flying by, defenders changing position, thinking becomes effortless. I can observe my surroundings, adjust my strategy to match them, and chart my course — all in a fraction of a second.

Having access to such a unique space for creative expression is probably a major reason why I enjoy playing basketball. But I never gave that kind of thing much thought. I was too busy trying to win the game.

Participating in legacy, then having it stripped away

During practice scrimmages freshman year, our coach occasionally gave the defensive team possession of the ball even if they were the ones to deflect it out of bounds. One day my teammate Cristal decided to protest this injustice.

“It was out on the defense!” she exclaimed. “It’s our ball!”

Coach kept Cristal after practice to lecture her about back-talk, but immediately following the first inaccurate call of the next day’s scrimmage, Cristal pointed out her team should be allowed to keep possession of the ball.

‘“It was a test, Cristal!” Coach shrieked.

Our coach moved to Mississippi after the season ended, but “It was a test,” stuck with us. Even today, team members who never played a day under that coach or with Cristal, use the phrase to poke fun at situations that seem to possess a hidden layer. This is college basketball: a continuous, living organism through which players pass along pieces of themselves to future generations.

College athletes can’t help but see every practice, every game, every offseason as an opportunity to shape the program — so over the course of their careers, there is never a moment of rest or relaxation. That’s why all college basketball players have a little bit of an attitude. Because the vision you’re trying to execute into reality, the hours you’re committing, the hours your teammates alongside you are committing — those are things that nobody can see or touch.

In a few months I’ll head out into a world where I don’t know who my teammates are or to what vision I commit myself. For the first time in my life, I’m worried about what will become of my attitude — and of me.
